comment.text: Works for me, no regressions noticed.
No issue spotted with my setup
Just noticed that the i686 version of chromium-libs is several times larger than the release version (163M as opposed to 43M for the release version). This doesn't happen on x86_64. Is that expected?

bugs.title: CVE-2017-5055 chromium-browser: use after free in printing

bugzilla.short_desc: CVE-2017-5055 chromium-browser: use after free in printing

long_desc.thetext:
An use after free flaw was found in the printing component of the Chromium browser.

Upstream bug(s):

https://code.google.com/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=698622

External References:

https://chromereleases.googleblog.com/2017/03/stable-channel-update-for-desktop_29.html

Created chromium tracking bugs for this issue:

Affects: fedora-all [bug 1437355]

This issue has been addressed in the following products:

  Red Hat Enterprise Linux 6 Supplementary

Via RHSA-2017:0860 https://access.redhat.com/errata/RHSA-2017:0860

This is an automatically created tracking bug!  It was created to ensure
that one or more security vulnerabilities are fixed in affected versions
of Fedora.

For comments that are specific to the vulnerability please use bugs filed
against the "Security Response" product referenced in the "Blocks" field.

For more information see:
http://fedoraproject.org/wiki/Security/TrackingBugs

When submitting as an update, use the fedpkg template provided in the next
comment(s).  This will include the bug IDs of this tracking bug as well as
the relevant top-level CVE bugs.

Please also mention the CVE IDs being fixed in the RPM changelog and the
fedpkg commit message.

NOTE: this issue affects multiple supported versions of Fedora. While only
one tracking bug has been filed, please correct all affected versions at
the same time.  If you need to fix the versions independent of each other,
you may clone this bug as appropriate.

[bug automatically created by: add-tracking-bugs]

Use the following template to for the 'fedpkg update' request to submit an
update for this issue as it contains the top-level parent bug(s) as well as
this tracking bug.  This will ensure that all associated bugs get updated
when new packages are pushed to stable.

=====

# bugfix, security, enhancement, newpackage (required)
type=security

# testing, stable
request=testing

# Bug numbers: 1234,9876
bugs=1437348,1437350,1437351,1437352,1437353,1437355

# Description of your update
notes=Security fix for CVE-2017-5055, CVE-2017-5054, CVE-2017-5052, CVE-2017-5056, CVE-2017-5053

# Enable request automation based on the stable/unstable karma thresholds
autokarma=True
stable_karma=3
unstable_karma=-3

# Automatically close bugs when this marked as stable
close_bugs=True

# Suggest that users restart after update
suggest_reboot=False

======

Additionally, you may opt to use the bodhi web interface to submit updates:

https://bodhi.fedoraproject.org/updates/new

bugs.title: Chromium high resolution touchpad scrolling broken under Xwayland

bugzilla.short_desc: Chromium high resolution touchpad scrolling broken under Xwayland

long_desc.thetext:
Description of problem:
Under XWayland, touchpad scrolling moves in discrete steps. This is covered in the upstream bug crbug.com/712737.

To summarize, X clients that use high resolution scrolling will lose the first discrete mouse wheel tick after focus is gained. This is a general problem of X, see https://bugzilla.gnome.org/show_bug.cgi?id=750994.

Chromium has a heuristic that tries to work around this, but on Fedora the heuristic doesn't work on X and breaks hi-res scrolling on XWayland.

Until a solution is found upstream, Fedora Chromium would benefit from a patch that reverts https://crrev.com/b794998819088f76b4cf44c8db6940240c563cf4


Version-Release number of selected component (if applicable):
chromium-57.0.2987.133-1.fc25.x86_64

How reproducible:
Always.


Steps to Reproduce:
1. Use libinput X input driver or Wayland.
2. Scroll with a touchpad.

Actual results:
Under X, the scrolling is high resolution but mouse wheel ticks are still lost. Under Wayland, high resolution scrolling doesn't work.

Expected results:
High resolution scrolling everywhere. (And maybe no lost mouse wheel ticks.)
